title: Fire chief jailed after being falsely accused of historic child sex abuse blames police for his wife’s death
text:
Fire chief jailed after being falsely accused of historic child sex abuse blames police for his wife’s death Lynn Bryant has died just six months after her husband was finally freed Credit: Russell Sach Robert Mendick , Chief Reporter   
A fire chief jailed after being falsely accused of historic child sex abuse has blamed police for his wife’s death at the age of 54 because of the stress caused by his wrongful conviction. 
Lynn Bryant has died just six months after her husband was finally freed after spending almost three years in prison for a crime he did not commit. 
Her husband David, 66, from Christchurch in Dorset broke down in tears as he told The Telegraph of his wife’s deep distress at police’s continued refusal to apologise for its bungled investigation into the false claims, made by a serial liar and fantasist. 
Mrs Bryant died on February 13 from sepsis, a potentially lethal condition which occurs when the body’s immune system goes into overdrive during an infection. Mr and Mrs Bryant suffered a ‘living hell’ Credit: RUSSELL SACH 
M r and Mrs Bryant suffered a ‘living hell’ after Danny Day, who suffered serious mental health problems, went to police in 2012 falsely claiming the fire chief, with an unblemished record, had raped him on one occasion at the local fire station 35 years ago when he was 14. 
The case was finally quashed by the Court of Appeal which declared Mr Bryant innocent in July. 
But Dorset police has still refused to apologise. Mr Bryant told The Sunday telegraph: “I think the stress killed her. You couldn’t prove it but it stands to reason that all that stress cannot have done her any good . 
“If Dorset police had given us a timely apology that would have helped Lynn. That is all we really wanted. What really upset her was that we asked for the paperwork on the police case and they said; ‘you cannot have it because it would go against Danny day’s human rights’. That really upset her.” 
Mrs Bryant’s tireless detective work after her husband was jailed was a major factor in securing his release. 
Evidence uncovered by Mrs Bryant and her legal team showed Day, who waived his right to anonymity, had sought medical help for compulsive lying. Dave was sentenced to six years in prison Credit: RUSSELL SACH 
R upert Butler, the Bryant’s lawyer, who is bringing a claim against police on Mr Bryant’s behalf, said in a moving tribute: “Lynn Bryant was a woman of incredible faith. When her world collapsed in 2012 she stayed true to her instincts and stuck by her hero, Dave, knowing he was innocent and knowing that decision would cause her many problems. 
“She suffered social isolation and attacks on her house, gruelling journeys between Christchurch and Dartmoor for prison visits and financial hardships - even having to sell her beloved jewellery that held so many happy memories.” 
Mr Butler added: “When Dave’s conviction was eventually quashed it was as much down to her tenacity as anything else. She fought against the system, in spite of formidable odds, and she won. 
“What she really wanted was for Dorset Police to admit it had failed Dave and to apologise, but this has not yet happened. 
“I have no doubt that the stress of these last four years of fighting tooth-and-nail took a considerable physical toll on Lynn that finally broke her body, but not her spirit. It has been a great reassurance to know that she and Dave were able to spend happy months together after his release from prison. Hers and Dave’s is an extraordinary love story that deserved a far longer final chapter.” 
Dorset police was unavailable for comment today. 
It has said in the past: “Dorset Police takes allegations of this nature very seriously and conducted a very thorough and detailed investigation. The findings of the investigation were passed on to the Crown prosecution Service who chose to prosecute.” Follow Telegraph News
